editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: The politician, a tragedy written by James Shirley.
titleStmt.author: Shirley, James, 1596-1666.

note.p: "Presented at Salisbury court by Her Majesties servants."
Reproduction of original in Bristol Public Library, Bristol, England.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.p: The politician, a tragedy, presented at Salisbury court by her majesty's servants;
London, printed for Humphrey Moseley and are to be sold at his shop at the prince's arms in st. Paul's churchyard. 1655.

div.head: To the very much honoured Walter Moyle, esq
div.p: Though the severity of the times took away those dramatic recreations (Whose language so much glorified the English scene) and perhaps looking at some abuses of the common theatres, which were not so happily purged from scurrility, and underwit, (The only entertainment of vulgar capacities) they have outed the more noble and ingenious actions of the eminent stages; the rage yet hath not been epidemical, there are left many lovers of this exiled posy, who are great masters of reason, and that dare conscientiously own this musical part of humane learning, when it is presented without the stains of impudence and profanation.

Among these persons, sir you deserve an honourable inscription. For my own part; this is the last which is like to salute the public view in this
kind, and I have only to say, that I congratulate my own happiness to conclude with so judicious a patron.

To make a doubt of your fair receiving this piece: were to dishonour your character, and make myself undeserving. Read at your leisure, what is humbly presented to your eye and judgement, while I preserve my confidence in your virtue and good thoughts upon

closer.signed: The most humble honourer of your worth James Shirley

div.head: The names and small characters of the persons.

list.item: King of Norway, easy and credulous in his nature, and passionately doting upon Queen Marpisa.
Gotharus, the politician, active to serve his pleasures and ambition, a great favourite of the Queen.
Turgesius, the prince, of a gallant disposition, and honoured by the soldier.
Duke Olaus, the King's uncle, old, choleric and distasted with the court-proceedings, disaffected to Gotharus, and the Queen, but resolute, and faithful to the prince.
Haraldus son to Marpisa, young, of a sweet and noble disposition, whom Gotharus would form more bold, and ambitious for the greatness he had designed.
Sueno, Helga a couple of court-parasites.
Marpisa the Queen, a 'Proud subtle and revengeful lady, from the widow of count Altomarus, advanced to royal condition, by the practice of her creature and confident, Gotharus.
Albina, wife to Gotharus a virtuous but suffering lady, under the tyranny of an imperious, and disloyal husband.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It was a strange and sudden marriage.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Could he not love her for the game, and so forth,
But he must thus exalt her? no less title
Than Queen, to satisfy her ambition?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: 'Tis a brave rise!

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I did not prophesy,
When the honest count her husband Altomarus
Lived, she would bring us on our knees.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I hope
She'll love the King for't.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: And in his absence,
Gotharus the King's minion, her old friend,
He has done this royal service; beside, what
Rests on accounts in her old husband's days.
I do suspect her son Haraldus was
Got with more heat, and blood, than Altomarus
Age could assure her, but he's dead.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: — Be with him;
Although I won't make oath for her chastity,
That boys good nature is an argument
To me, Gotharus had no share in him:
He's honest, of a gentle disposition,
And on my conscience does pray sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No more, we have a wolf by th' ear, what news
From hell? he cannot want intelligence, he has
So many friends there — he's displeased, there is
Some goodness in that letter, I will pawn
My head, that makes him angry.
sp.stage: Enter some with petitions, Gotharus frowns upon 'em, they return hastily.
sp.l: How his frown
Hath scattered 'em like leaves, they fly from him
As nimbly, as their bodies had no more weight
Than their petitions; I would give an eye-tooth,
To read but three lines.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Curse upon his victory!
I meant him not this safety, when I wrought
The King to send him forth to war, but hoped
His active spirit would have met some engine
To have translated him to another world;
He's now upon return. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Would I had but
The harrowing of your skull; my genius gives me ▪
That paper is some good news of the prince,
I would I knew it but concerned him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: 'Twas
My wonder, the King would send his son abroad
to wars, the only pledge of his succession.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He had a councillor, this politician,
That would prefer the prince to heaven, a place
His lordship has no hope to be acquainted with;
The prince, and his great uncle Duke Olaus,
Would not allow these pranks of state, nor see
The King betrayed to a concubine;
Therefore it was thought fit they should be engaged
To foreign dangers.
sp.stage: Enter Albina, and her waiting woman.
sp.l: 'Tis madam Albina,
Our great man's wife.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: The King did seem to affect her,
Before he married her to his favourite.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Dost think she's honest?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I'll not stake my soul on't,
But I believe she is too good for him,
Although the King and she have private conference.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: She looks as she were discontent. Exit Al.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: She has cause
In being Gotharus' wife, some say she loved him
Most passionately.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: 'Twas her destiny;
She has him now, and if she love him still,
'Tis not impossible she may be a martyr,
His proud and rugged nature will advance
Her patience to't.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Avoid the gallery.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: The King is coming, o my lord, your pardon:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Nay we must all obey.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I ne'er liked
This fellow.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: He is one of fortunes minions ▪
the love of the choice ladies of the laundry,
That's one that draws in the same team, but more
Inclined to'th knave; he is a kind of pendant
To the King's ear, an everlasting parasite:
The King? Albina returned with him. Exit.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Leave us.
You're most unkind to yourself in my opinion,
You know well who I am, and what I have
Advanced you too; neither in virgin state
Nor marriage, to allow your King a favour?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sir, let the humble duty of a subject,
Who shall with zealous prayers solicit heaven
For you, and your fair Queen —

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Had you been wise,
That might have been your title, but the god
Of love had with his arrow so engraven
Gotharus in your heart; you had no language
But what concerned his praise, scarce any thought
At liberty; I did imagine, when
I had compassion of your sufferings,
And gave thee a fair bride to my Gotharus,
You would not lose the memory of my benefit,
But (Now in state, and nature to reward it)
Consented to return me love.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Be pleased
To excuse the boldness of one question.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Be free Albina.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Do not you love my husband?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: There wants no testimony, beside the rest,
My giving thee to him, dear to my thoughts,
Is argument I love him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Would you take
Me back again? you but betrayed his faith,
And your own gift, to tempt me to forsake him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You are more apprehensive, if you please
He shall possess you still, I but desire
Sometimes a near and loving conversation,
Though he should know't, considering how much
I may deserve, he would be wise enough
To love thee near the worse; he's not the first
Lord that hath purchased offices by the free
Surrender of his wife to the King's use,
'Tis frequent in all commonwealths to lend
Their playfellows to a friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O do not think
Gotharus can be worth your love, to be
So most degenerate, and lost to honour;
You have a Queen, to whom your vow is sacred,
Be just to her, the blessing is yet warm
Pronounced by holy priest, stain not a passion
To wander from that beauty, richer far
Than mine; let your souls meet and kiss each other,
That while you live, the examples of chaste love
(Most glorious in a King and Queen) we may
Grow up in virtue by the spring of yours,
Till our top-boughs reach heaven.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You are resolved than
We must be strangers, should my life depend
On the possession of your bosom, I
Should languish and expire, I see.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Good heaven
Will not permit the King want so much goodness,
To think the enjoying of forbidden pleasure
Could benefit his life, rather let mine
Ebb at some wound, and wander with my blood
By your command taken from me, on my knee —

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Rise, I may kiss Albina —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Ha!Enter Gotharus.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Thas shot
Another flame into me, come you must —

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Be a woman, do't, or I'll complain.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thy husband.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Horror!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Think upon't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What will become of miserable Albina?
Like a poor deer pursued to a steep precipice,
That overlooks the sea, by some fierce hound;
The just of a wild King doth threaten here,
Before me, the neglects of him I love,
Gotharus my unkind lord, like the waves,
And full as deaf affright me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How now madam?
Come, can you kiss?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Kiss sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What difference
Between his touch and mine now? his perhaps
Was with more heat, but mine was soft enough.
What has he promised thee, but that's no matter,
Thou wilt be wise enough to make thy bargain,
I father all, only the King shall give it
A name, he'll make it master of a province.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What means my lord:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou thinkst I am jealous now, not I, I knew
Before he doted on thee, and it is
To be presumed, having a veil to hide
Thy blushes, (I do mean our marriage)
Thou mayst find out some time to meet, and mingle
Storeys and limbs, it may be necessary;
And 'cause I will be dutiful to the King,
We will converse no more a-bed, I'll be
Thy husband still Albina, and wear my buds
Under my hair close like a prudent statesman;
But 'twere not much amiss, as I advised
Before, and these new premises considered,
you appear abroad with a less train, your wardrobe
Will make you more suspected, if it be
Too rich; and some whole days to keep your chamber,
Will make the King know where to find you certain.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Will you have patience my lord to hear me?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The world doth partly think thee honest too,
That will help much, if you observe good rules
And diet, without tedious progresses,
And visiting of ladies, expert in
Night revels, masks, and twenty other torments
To an estate; your doctors must be left too,
I won't pay a fee to have your pulse
Felt, and your hand rolled up like wax, by one
Whose foot-cloth must attend, while he makes legs,
And every other morning comes to tell
Your ladyship a story out of Aretine,
That can set you a longing for diseases,
That he may cure you, and your waiting-woman,
Whose curiosity would taste your glister,
Commend the operation from her stomach.
Should you be sick, and sick to death, I would
Not counsel you to physic; women are
Frail things, and should a cordial miscarry,
My conscience would be arraigned, and I
Might be suspected for your poisoner.
No, no, I thank you, you're in a fine course
To ease me wife; or if you must be loose,
I'th spring and fall, let the King bear the charges.
He will, if you apply yourself.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am wretched;
Why do you without hearing thus condemn me?
The lady lives not with a purer faith
To her loved lord, than I have; nor shall greatness,
Nor death itself, have power to break it.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Come,
these are but painted tears, leave this, have you
Prepared your last accounts?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: They are ready sir;
Never was lady slaved thus like Albina,
A stipendiary, worse, a servile steward,
To give him an account of all my expenses.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I'll have it so in spite of customs heart,
While you are mine; accountless liberty
Is ruin of whole families: now leave me,Exit Al.
We may talk more anon, I have observed
This privacy before, search here Gotharus,
'Tis here from whence mutinous thoughts conspiring
With witty melancholy, shall beget
A strong born mischief, I'll admit she be
Honest, I love her not, and if he tempt her
To sin, that's paid him back in his wife's looseness;
From whom I took my first ambition,
And must go on, till we can sway the kingdom,
Though we climb to't o'er many deaths. I first
Practise at home, my unkindness to Albina,
If she do love me must needs break her heart.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Most dear Haraldus welcome,
Preciously welcome to Gotharus' heart.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The Queen my mother, sir, would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How excellently do those words become thee,
'Tis fit Haraldus mother be a Queen,
Thou'rt worth a princely fate; I will attend her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'll tell her so.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis not an office for you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: It is my duty sir, to wait upon
My mother.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Who i'th court is not your servant?
You do not exercise command enough,
You are too gentle in your fortune's sir,
And wear your greatness, as you were not born
To be a prince.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My birth sure gave me not
That title, I was born with the condition
To obey, not govern.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Do not wrong those stars,
Which early as you did salute the world,
Designed this glorious fate; I did consult,
And in the happy minute of thy birth,
Collect what was decreed in heaven about thee.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Those books are above my reading, but whate'er
My stars determine of me, 'tis but late
I heard my mother say, you are on earth,
To whom I am most bound for what I am:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis a shrewd truth, if thou knew'st all.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You have
Been more a father then a friend to us.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Friend to thy mother, I confess in private,
The other follows by a consequence,Aside.
A father my Haraldus? I confess
I was from thy nativity inclined
By a most strange and secret force of nature,
Or sympathy to love thee like my own;
And let me tell thee, though thy mother had
Merit enough to engage my senses;
Yet there was something more in thee considered,
That raised my thoughts, and study to advance
Thee to these pregnant hopes of state, methinks
I see thee a King already.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Good sir, do not
Prompt me to that ambition, I possess
Too much already, and I could, so pleased
My mother, travel where I should not hear
Of these great titles, and it comes now aptly,
I should entreat your lordship to assist me
In a request to her, I know she loves you,
And will deny you nothing; I would fain
Visit the university for study,
I do lose time methinks.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Fie Haraldus,
And leave the court? how you forget yourself?
Study to be King,
I shall half repent my care,
If you permit these dull and phlegmatic
Thoughts to usurp, they'll stifle your whole reason,
Catch at the sun, divest him of his beam,
And in your eye wear his proud rays; let day
Be when you smile, and when your anger points,
Shoot death in every frown: covet a shade,
Affect a solitude, and books, and forfeit,
So brave an expectation?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Of Norway's crown.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Could there be any thought
Within me so ambitious, with what hope
Could it be cherished, when I have no title?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I that have thus far studied thy fortune,
May find a way.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The King —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Is not immortal while he has physicians.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What's that unsaided? The King is happy,
And the whole nation treasure up their hopes
In prince Turgesius, who with his great uncle
Valiant Olaus.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Are sent to'th wars, where 'twill concern 'em,
To think of fame, and how to march to honour
Through death.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I dare not hear him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Or if they
return —

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: They will be welcome to all good
Men's hearts, and next the King, none with more joy
Congratulate their safeties, than yourself:
I am confident my lord you will remember
To see my mother, and excuse me if
To finish something else I had in charge,
I take my leave, all good dwell with your lordship.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But that I have Marpisa's faith, I could
Suspect him not the issue of my blood,
He is too tame, and honest, at his years
I was prodigiously in love with greatness;
Or if not mine, let him inherit but
His mother's soul, she has pride enough, and spirit
To catch at flames, his education
Has been too soft, I must new form the boy
Into more vice, and daring, strange, we must
Study at court, how to corrupt our children ▪
The Queen!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My expectation to speak
With thee Gotharus, was too painful to me;
I fear we are all undone; dost hear the news?
The prince is coming back with victory,
Our day will be o'ercast.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: These eyes will force
A brighter from those clouds; are not you Queen?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But how Turgesius, and his bold uncle
Will look upon me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Let 'em stare out
Their eyeballs, be you mistress still of the
King's heart, and let their gall spout in their stomach,
We'll be secure.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Thou art my fate.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I must confess
I was troubled when I heard it first; seem not
You pale at their return, but put on smiles
To grace their triumph; now you have most need
Of woman's art, dissemble cunningly.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My best Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They shall find stratagems in peace, more fatal
Than all the engines of the war; what mischief
Will not Gotharus fly to, to assure
The fair Marpisa's greatness, and his own,
In being hers (An empire above the world)
There is a heaven in either eye, that calls
My adoration, such Promethean fire,
As were I struck dead in my works, shouldst thou
But dart one look upon me, it would quicken
My cold dust, and inform it with a soul
More daring than the first.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Still my resolved Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Let weak statesmen think of conscience,
I am armed against a thousand stings, and laugh at
The tales of hell, and other worlds, we must
Possess our joys in this, and know no other
But what our fancy every minute shall
Create to please us.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This is harmony,
How dull is the King's language, I could dwell
Upon thy lips; why should not we engender
At every sense?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Now you put me in mind,
The pledge of both our hopes, and blood, Haraldus,
Is not well bred, he talks too morally,
He must have other discipline, and be fashioned
For our great aims upon him; a crown never
Became a Stoic, pray let me commend
Some conversation to his youth.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He is thine. Enter Helga.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: He shall be every way my own.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: The King desires your presence madam.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I attend, you'll follow —Exit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thee to death, and triumph in
My ruins for thy sake, a thousand forms
Throng in my brain, that is the best, which speeds,
Who looks at crowns, must have no thought who bleeds. Exit.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This music doth but add to melancholy,
I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He's strangely moved.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I cannot think a cause,
You were wont to fool him into mirth; where's Helga
Your dear companion? no device between you
To raise his thoughts?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I am nothing without my fellow,
Music is best in consort.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Your buffoonery is musical belike.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Your juggler's cannot do some o'their tricks
Without confederacy.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I'll try alone.
If please your majesty there is —

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: That for your unseasonable and saucy fooling.Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That was a musical box o'th' ear.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing without a fellow, he knows
Music is best in consort. Exit.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Would you had your parts?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hormenus you may stay.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Men do account thee honest.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: 'Tis possible
I may fare the worse.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And wise; canst tell the cause why I am sad?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nor I myself, 'tis strange I should be subject
To a dull passion, and no reason for it.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: These things are frequent.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sometimes ominous,
And do portend.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you enjoy a health,
What is in fate?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am King
Still, and I not?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We are all happy in't,
And when time shall with the consent of nature,
Call you an old man from this world to heaven,
May he that shall succeed you, prince Turgesius,
The glory of our hope, be no less fortunate.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My son,
I was too rash to part with him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We should
Have thought his stay a blessing, and did wish
You would not have exposed such tender years
To the rough war; but your commands met with
His duty, and our obedience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It is very
Strange, we of late hear no success, I hope
This sadness is not for his loss, he has
A kinsman with him, loves him dear, 'tis
The Queen. Enter Queen and Helga.
I feel my drooping thoughts fall off,
And my clouds fly before the wind, her presence
Hath an infusion to restore dead nature.
My sweet, my dear Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You sent for me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am but the shadow of myself without thee.
No wonder I was sad, my soul had placed
All her delight in these fair eyes, and could not
But think itself an exile in thy absence,
Why should we ever part, but chain ourselves
Together thus?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: He's in a better humour I hope;
I do not think but his majesty would cuff well,
His hand carries a princely weight.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: A favour.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Would you might wear such another in your ear.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come hither — on this side.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You were on that side before.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Wouldst not thou lose thy life, to do a service
My Queen would smile upon?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Alas, my life
Is the least thing to be imagined, he
Is not a faithful subject would refuse
To kill his wife and children, after that
To hang himself, to do the Queen a service.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come hither Helga.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Royal sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What would affright thy undertaking, to deserve
The least grace from my Queen?

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
But I've an opinion, the devil could not;
My life is nothing fir, to obtain her favour,
I would hazard more; I have heard talk of hell,
So far she should command me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Bless me goodness!
What wretched parasites are these? how can
The King be patient at 'em? here is flattery
so thick and gross, it would endure a handsaw.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: His judgement's I fear stupefied.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come hither,
Which of you can resolve, what serpent spawned you?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You are pleasant.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: My good lord, it hurts not you,
There is necessity of some knaves, and so
Your lordship be exempted, why should you
Trouble yourself, and murmur at our courses?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Your business?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: News from the field.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Good?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: The day, the field, the safety, oh the glory
Of war is Norway's, letters to the King —

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Give 'em to me.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Or me.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Trust not a fool with things of consequence,
He's the King's mirth, let me present the news.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Sir, I should know you; this is a knave,
Would take to him all the glory of your report;
If please you, let me present the letters.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: My liege!

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: My sovereign!

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: News!

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Good news!

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Excellent news!

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: The prince ▪

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: The prince is —

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: The enemy is — o'erthrown.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: They have lost the day.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Defeated utterly.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: And are all slain.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Madam, will you hear the news?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Say on, what is't you would relate?

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: One of my creatures sir hath brought you letters,Aquinus delivers the letters.
My servant sir, one strengthened to your service
Out of my maintenance, an instrument of mine,
So please you to consider my duty in his service.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Why hark you gentlemen, I have but mocked
Your greedy zeals, there's no such matter in
Those letters as you have told; we have lost all,
And the prince taken prisoner, will you not
Stay for the reward, you know I'm but your creature,
I look for nothing but your courtly faces
To pay my travel.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: We won't appear yet —Exit.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: How the rats vanish.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Read here my best Marpisa, news that makes
A triumph in my heart, great as the conquest
Upon our enemies; Hormenus, Cortes,
Our son will prove a soldier, was my sadness
Omen to this good fate? or nature feared
The ecstasy of my joy would else o'ercome me?
They are returned victorious.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thanks to heaven!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And some reward is due to thee; wear that
For the King's sake.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: You too much honour me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But something in Marpisa's face, shows not
So clear a joy as we express, forbear,Exeunt.
Wait till we call; can this offend my Queen,
To hear of happiness to my son? O let
Thy eyes look bright, there shine hath force to make
the wreath of laurel grow upon his temples;
Why dost thou weep? this dew will kill the victory,
And turn his bay to cypress.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Witness heaven,
There's not a tear that mourns for him, his safety
And conquest is most welcome, and he shall
Have still my prayers, he may grow up in fame,
And all the glorious fortunes of a prince:
But while my wishes fly to heaven for blessings
Upon his head, at the same time, I must
Remember in what miserable condition
My stars have placed me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What can make thy state
Guilty of such a name, and so deject
Thy nobler thoughts? am not I still the King?
And is not fair Marpisa mine by marriage?
Crowned here my Queen immortally.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Though I be
By royal bounty of your love, possessed
Of that great title sir, I have some fears.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You amaze me, speak thy doubts at large.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: The prince
(Dear to your love, and I still wish him so)
(Dear to your people's hearts) I fear, will think
Our marriage his dishonour, and Olaus
Your passionate uncle, no good friend of mine,
When he shall see to what a height your love
And holy vow hath raised me, most unworthy,
Will but salute Marpisa with his scorn,
And by his counsel, or some ways of force
Unchain our hearts, and throw me from your bosom
To death, or worse, to shame; o think upon me,
And if you have one fear that's kin to mine,
Prevent their tyranny, and give me doom
Of exile ere their cruelty arrive:
I'll take my sentence kindly from your lips,
Though it be killing.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let my son or uncle,
Dare but affront three in a look, I shall
Forget the ties of nature, and discharge 'em
Like the corruption in my blood.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I can
Submit myself to them, and would you please
To allow my humbleness no stain to what
You have advanced me to, I can be their servant,
And with as true a duty wait upon 'em —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou art all goodness, twenty kingdoms are
Too little for thy dowry; who attends?
Thus every minute I will marry thee,
And wear thee in my heart, vanish the thought
Of all thy sex beside, and what can else
Attempt our separation: thou'rt obscure,
And livest in court but like a masking star,
Shut from us by the unkindness of a cloud
When Cynthia goes to revels: I will have
A chariot for my Queen richer than ere
Was shown in Roman triumph, and thou shalt
Be drawn with horses white as Venus' doves,
Till heaven itself in envy of our bliss,
Snatch thee from earth to place thee in his orb,
The brightest constellation.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He dotes strangely.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hormenus, Cortes, I would have you all
Search your inventions to advance new joys;
Proclaim all pleasures free, and while my fair
Queen smiles, it shall be death for any man
I'th court to frown. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You ha' not so much love i'th court Aquinus.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: How do you like the Queen?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Why she's not married,
He does but call her so.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And lies with her.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: The prince yet knows it not.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He'll meet it coming home.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Aquinus? Enter Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You brought letters from the camp.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I did my lord.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What in the name of policy is now hatching?
I do not like those fawning postures in him,
How kind they are.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: That soldier is thought honest.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But if he cringe once more I shall suspect him,
That leg confirms he is corrupt already.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How does he like his father's marriage?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: We had no fame on't there when I set forth.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'T was strange and sudden, but we are all happy
In the good prince's health and victory;
The Duke Olaus too I hope is well.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He was designed at my departure,
To be here before the army.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He will be welcome:
You shall accept the price of a new armour,
And wherein any power of mine can serve you
I'th court, command.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I am your lordship's creature. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They are gone, I long to see the prince ▪
How do you think his highness will
Behave himself to his new mother Queen?
Will it be treason not to ask her blessing?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I am confident his uncle, brave Olaus.
Won't run mad for joy of the King's marriage?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let them look to't, there may be alterations.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: They talk sure of my mother and the King.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Secure as they account themselves, the prince
Must be received spite of Marpisa's greatness,
And all the tricks of her incarnate fiend
Gotharus, who both plot I fear, to raise
That composition of their blood,
Haraldus —

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How was that?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: The strange effect
Of their luxurious appetites, though in him
Poor innocence, suspecting not their sin,
We read no such ambition.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: O my shame!
What have my ears received? am I a bastard?
'Tis malice that doth wound my mother's honour;
How many bleed at once? yet now I call
To memory, Gotharus at our loving
Late conference, did much insult upon
The name of a father, and his care of me
By some strange force of nature: ha! my fears
Shoot an ice through me, I must know the truth
Although it kill me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Who was that Haraldus?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I hope he did not hear us, again Gotharus.
And the two squirrels; more devices yet.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Let us alone my lord, we'll quicken him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You must use all your art to win him to't.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Let us alone to make him drink, we are the credit
Of the court for that, he's but a child alas, we'll take our time.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Hormenus.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: My good lord Olaus, I
Joy in your safe return, how fares the prince?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Well, where's the King?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Kissing his new made Queen Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ha!
The King is married then. Exit Su. and ho.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Away, the Duke Olaus, sir —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I am too stiff for compliment,
My lord, I have rid hard —Exit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He has met the intelligence,
And is displeased with me the state of things at home;
This marriage stings him, let it, we must have
No trembling hearts, not fall into an ague,
Like children at the sight of a portent:
But like a rock when wind and waves go highest,
And the insulting billows dash against
Her ribs, be unmoved. The King must be saluted
With other letters, which must counterfeit
The prince's character, I was his secretary
And know the art, malice inspire my brain
To poison his opinion of his son;
I'll form it cunningly.
Ha! 'tis Haraldus.
He looks sad.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I dare not ask
My mother, 'twere a crime, but one degree
Beneath the sinful act that gave me life
To question her, and yet to have this fright
Dwell in my apprehension, without
The knowledge of some truth, must needs distract
My poor wits quite; 'tis he, I will take boldness
And know the worst of him, if I be what
I am already charactered, he can
Resolved my shame too well.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How is't my lord?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Never so ill sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Art sick?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Most dangerously.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Here, at heart, which bleeds with such a wound,
As none but you, can cure.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I'll drop my soul
Into it, show me how I may
Be thy physician, to restore thy blood
I will lose all mine, speak child.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: This very love
Is a fresh suffering, and your readiness
To cure my sorrow, is another wound;
You are too kind, why are you so? what is
Or can be thought in me fit to deserve it?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou dost talk wildly; to accuse me thus
For loving thee, could the world tempt me here,
And court me with her glories to forsake thee,
Thus I would dwell about thy neck, and not
Be bought from kissing thee for all her provinces:
There is a charm upon my soul to love thee,
And I must do't.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Then I must die.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Forbid it gentler fates.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If I could hear you wish
Me dead, I should have hope to live; although
I would not willingly deserve your anger,
By any impious deed, you do not know
What comfort it would be to hear you curse me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He's mad; Haraldus, prithee do not talk so.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Or if you think a curse too much to help me,
Yet rail upon me, but do't heartily, and call me

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Villain, or bastard, sir,
The worst is best from you.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou dost amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Will you not for me?
Then for my mother's sake if you do love her,
Or ever did esteem her worth your friendship,
Let me entreat you draw your sword, and give me
Something to wear in blood upon my bosom;
Write but one letter of your name upon
My breast, I'll call you father, by your love;
Do something that may make me bleed a little.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: By that I dare not, thou hast named Haraldus
A father.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I but call you so, I know
You are a stranger to my blood, although
Indeed to me your great affection
Appears a wonder; nor can nature show
More in a parent to a child; but if
I be.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I shall blush sir to pronounce it,
There's something that concerns my mother, will not
Give it a name; yet I would be resolved,
That I might place my duty right; if I
Must answer to your son, you may imagine
I shall no more ask you a reason, why
You have been so kind to me; and to my mother.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou hast said it, thou'rt mine own, 'twas nature in me,
That could not hide the actions of a father.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am your base seed then.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Stain not thyself
With such a name, but look upon thy mother
Now made a Queen.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You made her first a strumpet,
And it would ask the piety of her son,
To die upon that man that stole her honour:
Why did you so undo us? why did you
Betray my mother to this shame? or when
she had consented, why should both your lust
Curse my unsinning heart, o I must be
For your vice scorned, though innocent.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: None dare —

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I should not by your virtue have been saved,
Where shall I hide my life, I must no more
Converse with men —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou art too passionate.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I will entreat my mother we may go
Into some wilderness, where we may find
Some creatures that are spotted like ourselves,
And live and die there, be companion
To the wild panther, and the leopard, yet
They are too good for their converse, we are
By ours, defiled, their spots do make them fair.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis time that Sueno and his companion,
Dispersed these clouds; now to the King, with whom
If the Queen's beauty keep her magic, than
Our engine mount, and day grows bright again.

div.head: Act. 3.
div.stage: Enter King, Queen, Olaus, Reginaldus, Aguinus, Helga.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Uncle, I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I am not glad
To see you sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Not me?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Consorted thus.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If Olaus be forgetful of good manners,
I shall forget his years, and blood; be temperate.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: There's something in your blood that will undo
Your state and fame eternally, purge that,
You know I never flattered you, that woman
Will prove thy evil genius.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You're too saucy.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Do not I know her, was she not wife
To the count Altomarus a weak lord?
But too good for her, charmed by the flattery
And magic of her face, and tongue, to dote
And marry her, born of a private family,
Advanced thus, she grew insolent, and I fear
By pride and liberty, and some trick she had,
Broke her good husband's heart.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir, you much wrong me,
And now exceed the privilege of your birth
To injure mine.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: We all know you can plead
Your own defence, you have a woman's wit,
Heaven send you equal modesty, I am plain.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It would be held an insolence in others,
And saucy boldness in the sacred presence
Thus of the King, to accuse, whom he hath pleased
To take companion of his bed; and though
It would become the justice of my cause
And honour, to desire these black aspersions
May be examined further, and the author
Called to make proof of such a passionate language,
(Which will betray his accusation was
But envy of my fortunes) I remember
You're the King's uncle, and 'tis possible
You may be abused by some malicious tale
Framed to dishonour me, and therefore I
Beseech you humbly sir, to let this pass
But as an act in him of honest freedom,
Beside what else may give you privilege
being a soldier, and not used to file
His language, blunt and rugged ways of speech
Becoming your profession.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Very good!
Although we ha' not the device of tongue
And soft phrase madam, which you make an idol
At court, and use it to disguise your heart,
We can speak truth in our unpolished words,
Thou art —

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What am I?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Not the Queen.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: She is
My wife Olaus.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I must never kneel to her,
Nor the good prince your son, the hope of war,
And peace's darling, honour of our blood,
And worth a better kingdom than he's born to —

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Must never call her mother.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Dare you instruct him
Against his duty, leave us.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You have lost
More honour in those minutes you were married,
Than we have gained in months abroad, with all
Our triumph purchased for you with our blood;
Is this the payment, the reward for all
Our faith? when thy young son, whose springing valour
And name, already makes the confines tremble,
Returns like young Augustus crowned with victories;
Must a stepdame first salute him,
And tread upon his laurel?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Leave the court.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: May it not prove an hospital, 'tis i'th way
To change a title, lust and all the riots
Of licence reeling in it, by th'example
of one should least profane it, I am still
Oh laus, and your father's brother.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Take heed
You do not talk your head off, we have scaffolds,
But the old man raves, come my Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Then I will talk, threaten my head,
Command that parasite that dares do most
In wickedness, to show himself your servant;
Give him his engine, and his fee for hangman,
Let him take boldness but to move one hair
That withers on my head out of his posture,
He shall have more hope to o'ercome the devil
In single duel, than to scape my fury.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Our guard.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Look you, I'll bring no danger to your person,
I love you too well; I did always use
To speak, your father liked me near the worse.
And now I am cool again —
You say you are married —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Then between you, and I, and let none hear us,
To make yourself, your son, and kingdom prosper,
Be counselled to a divorce.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Not, not
To save thy soul, my son's life added
To thine, and lives of all the army shall
Be divorced from this world first, you are my father's
Brother, and if you love my son, your pupil,
So hopeful in your thoughts, teach him to come
More humbly to us, without thought to question
Our marriage, or I'll find a chastisement
For his rebellious heart, we will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol,
sp.l: You must not; I won't leave him yet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: This freedom may engage his life to danger,
He is too passionate.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He has said too much,
I'll venture speaking to him. Exit.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: He's alone, now to him.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Noble sir — I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: A courtier ask a suit of a soldier?
You'll wear no buff nor iron?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I come very impudently, and I hope to thrive
The better for't; this gentleman my friend,
A man of quality, and in some grace with
The King, hath laid a wager with me of
Two hundred crowns, I dare not pull a hair
From your most reverend beard: now if you please
To give me leave, I'll win the crowns, laugh at him,
And drink your health at supper.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: A hair from my beard?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: But one hair, if shall please you.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Come, take it.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I have pulled three noble sir.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: 'Twas more than your commission, there's one
That's another, and that will make you an upright courtier. Strikes him.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you —

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Beg modestly hereafter, take within your bounds,
You have small beard to play upon. 'tis fit
My fist should make an answer to your wit.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I have it to a hair, the choleric Duke again?
I am gone. Exeunt. Ent. Ol. and Aqui.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir, you have been too blame.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How dare you talk to me sir?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: 'Tis my duty, and I must tell you,
You've built too much upon him as a kinsman,
and have forgotten the King.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Take that for your impudence. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I have it, and I thank you.

div.stage: Enter King, reading of letters, Queen.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: They are gone sir, but have left prints of their fury,
The angry Duke has broke Aquinus' head,
For speaking dutifully on your behalf;
Tother mute man of war stroke Sueno sir.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I hear his language humming in my head still.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Aquinus? strike so near our presence?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Nay these soldiers will strike a man, if he do not
Carry himself to a hair's breadth, I know that.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: They shall repent this impudence, look up
My dear Marpisa, there's no tempest shall
Approach to hurt thee, they have raised a storm
To their own ruins.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Sir, if you'll bring me
To'th King. you shall do an office worth your labour,
I have letters will be welcome.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: You must give
Me leave sir to present 'em from the prince:
Most excellent, sir, my sovereign.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Letters? If you have a chain of gold —

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Go hang thyself. Soldier gives Helga the letters, and exit.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: I am most fortunate to present you sir
With letters from the prince, and if your majesty
Knew with what zeal I tender these.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: He frowns, where's the soldade? you'll go my half.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Who brought these letters? where's the messenger

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He was here but now, he's vanished.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Vanish thee too, and creep into the earth.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The impudence of children, read Marpisa,
More letters from the proud ambitious boy,
He dares to give us precepts, and writes here,
We have too much forgotten ourself and honour,
In making thee our Queen, puts on his grace
A discontent, and says, the triumph he
Expected, the reward of his young merit,
Will be ungloried in our sudden match,
And weak election.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: This was my fear.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He threatens us, if we proceed with his
Command and power i'th army; raise new forces
To oppose 'em, and proclaim 'em rebels, traitors —

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you for the general good,
Temper your rage, these are but words of passion,
The prince will soon be sorry for't, suspect not
His duty, rather than disgrace your son,
Divide me from your heart, the people love him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I'll hate him for't, Gotharus; where's Gotharus,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: This letter tastes of his invention,
He's active, it concerns us both. Albina.
Nay, you may forward madam.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I beseech
Your pardon, I did hope to have found my lord
Gotharus here.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: The King asked for him,
And is but new retired, who I presume
If he had known of your approach, would not
Have gone so soon.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I have no business madam
With the King.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Come do not disguise it thus,
I am covetous to know your suit;
But I am confident he will deny
You nothing, and your husband is of my
Opinion lately.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By your goodness madam,
Let me not suffer in your thoughts, I see
There is some poison thrown upon my innocence,
And 'tis not well done of my lord Gotharus,
To render me to your suspicion
So unhappy, 'tis too much he has withdrawn
His own heart, he will show no seeds of charity,
To make all others scorn me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: If he do,
You can return it, but take heed your ways
Be straight to your revenge, let not my fame
And honour be concerned with the least wound.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I understand not what you mean.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I cannot
Be patient, to hear the King commend
Your lip.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: My phrase is modest,
Do not you love the King?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes, with the duty —

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Of one that wants no cunning to dissemble
Her pride, and loose desires.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You are the Queen.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I should else tell you, 'tis ill done
To oppress one that groans beneath the weight ▪
Of grief already, and I durst take boldness
To say, you were unjust.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I can
Contain no longer, take from my sad heart
what hitherto I have concealed, (In that
You may call me dissembler of my sorrows)
I am weary of my life, and fear not what
Your power and rage can execute; would you
Had no more guilt upon your blood, than I
Have sin in my accounts that way, my lord
Gotharus would not be so unkind to me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What's that you said so impudently Albina?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What I did think should have consumed me here
In silence, but your injuries are mighty,
And though I do expect to have my name
In your black register designed for death,
To which my husband will I know consent;
I cannot thus provoked, but speak what wounds me.
Yet here again I shut the casket up,
Never to let this secret forth, to spread
So wide a shame hereafter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Thou hast waked
A lioness.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Death cannot more undo me,
And since I live an exile from my husband,
I will not doubt but you may soon prevail,
To give my weary soul a full discharge
Some way or other; and i'th minute when
It takes her flight to an eternal dwelling,
I will forgive you both, and pray for you,
But let not your revenge be to long idle,
Lest the unmeasured pile of my affections
Weigh me to death before your anger comes,
And so you lose the triumph of your envies.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You sha'not be forgotten, fear it not,
And but that something nearer doth concern us,
You should soon find a punishment. The King. Ex.

div.stage: Enter King, Gotharus, with a letter.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He struck Aquinus, Helga saw him bleed.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: These are strange insolences, one go for Aquinus.
Did Olaus bring these letters?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No, some spirit,
For he soon vanished.
I have given my son
To the most violent men under the planets,
These soldiers.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And they'll cling to him like ivy,
Embrace him even to death.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Like breeze to cattle
In summer, they'll not let him feed.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But make
Him fling, unquiet.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Most repineful, spleeny.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Ready to break the twist of his allegiance.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Which they fret every day —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: These put upon his young blood discontents.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Dangerous —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Extremely dangerous.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Swell him up
With the alluring shapes of rule, and empire —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And speak his strength with a proud emphasis;
Yours, with a faint cold-hearted voice; was ever
Such peremptory lines writ to a father?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thy counsel, while the dangers yet aloof.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Aloof? take heed, hills in a piece of landscape
May seem to stand a hundred leagues, yet measure,
There's but an inch in distance; o ambition
Is a most cunning, infinite dissembler,
But quick i'th execution.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He that aspires hath no religion,
He knows no kindred.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I ask for thy advice.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Have you not seen a great oak cleft asunder,
with a small wedge cut from the very heart
Of the same tree?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It frights me to apply it;
O my misfortune, this is torment, not
A cure. Enter Aquinus

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Aquinus, speak him gently sir,
And leave me to encourage him in a service
Worth his attempt, and needful to your safety.
Noble Aquinus, our good King has sense
Of the affront you suffered from his uncle,
And as he is informed, for speaking but
The duty of a subject.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: This is true sir,
I wear his bloody favour still, I never
Took any blow so long on trust.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I know thy spirit's daring, and it shall become
My justice to reward thy suffering;
A storm now hovers o'er my kingdom,
When the air is clear, and our sky fair again,
Expect, nay challenge, we shall recompense
What thou hast suffered for us, with a bounty
Worth all thy merits, i'th mean time apply
Thyself to my Gotharus, and be counselled. Exit.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: My duty.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou'st no alliance to my blood;
Yet if thou think'st I do not flatter thee,
I feel a friendly touch of thy dishonour,
The blow, 'twas not well done of Duke Olaus.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: You great men think you may do what you please,
And if you've a mind to pound us in a mortar
We must obey.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: That law is none of natures,
And this distinction of birth and royalty
Is not so firm a proof, but there are men
Have swords to pierce it through, and make the hearts
of those that take this privilege from their blood,
Repent they were injurious.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: My sword
Was quiet when he beat me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He did not, could not beat thee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: 'Twas worse, he cudgeled me, I feel it yet,
Nor durst I strike again.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: It could not be
A tameness in thy spirit, but quick thought
That 'twas Olaus, not, that in thy heart
There was no will to be revenged, for he
Is false to nature, loves his injury,
But that there was no safety to return
Thy anger on his person.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: You're i'th right,
That frighted me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: For he is not revenged,
That kills his enemy and destroys himself,
For doing his own justice, therefore men
That are not slaves, but free, these we receive
Born, and bred gentlemen in fair employments,
That have, and dare bid high again for honour,
When they are wronged by men above them in title,
As they are thought worthy a personal wound,
In that are raised and levelled with the injurer;
And he that shall provoke me with his weapon,
By making me his enemy, makes me equal,
And on those terms I kill him: but there is
Another caution to wise men, who ought
To cast and make themselves secure, that when
They have returned full payment for their sufferings
In fame, they may be safe without a guard.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: That sir is the prudence.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Yet I can direct thee
To be revenged with safety unto this,
What if I add therein, thou shalt do service
that will oblige the commonwealth, that groans
With fear of innovation, and make
The King thy friend by one expense of courage;
And having named the King thus, it must make
Thy thoughts secure from future loss, and in
The present act no danger.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Sir, be clear,
Make good what you have promised,
And see if I be frighted, I have helped
Many give up the ghost.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Olaus used
Thee basely, how much would the kingdom suffer
If he were dead and laid into his tomb,
Perhaps a year sooner than nature meant,
To make his bones fit.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I dare kill him sir,
If I were sure the King would pardon me,
That in my own revenge, and any other
Whom he calls enemy without exception,
To this I am bound in conscience; sir, there needs
No conjuration for this, nor art
To heighten me, let me but hear the King
Will have it, and secure me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou deservest him,
And mayst a statue, for our great deliverer,
Yet, now I have thought better on't, we may
Save trouble in Olaus' tragedy,
And kill him through another.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: One that
Sits heavier on the King's heart, and dwells in't
Such a disease, as if no resolute hand
Cure him.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I'll be his chirurgeon.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: When I name him,
One that has had no will to advance thee
to thy deserts in wars, for all thy former
And thy late services, rewarded with
A dull command of captain, but incensed
By Olaus now who rules his heart, less hope
To be repaired in fortune.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let him be the prince.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis he.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It honours my attempt;
And while his father holds him disobedient,
I think him less than subject.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Disobedient? look there. Shows a letter.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: This is the prince's hand.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But read his heart.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Impious! above the reach
Of common faith.
I am satisfied, he must not live; the way:
They would not trust me with his cup to poison it,
Show me the way — the King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Let's study. Enter King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: You have a faithful servant in Gotharus.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Upon his wisdom we depend.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I have it,
He shall die like a soldier, thus —Whispers.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Their malice
Doth only aim at me, and if you please
To give me up a sacrifice to their fury.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Not for a thousand sons, my life and honours
Must sit with thine Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: This act shall make thee great, the King and Queen
Look cheerful royal sir, and think of honour
To crown the merit of this captain, let
No trouble shake a thought, he will deserve
Your bosom sir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: He shall possess it; how my Gotharus?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Pray leave it to me, it is not ripe yet for your knowledge sir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: We'll trust thee, come Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Dearest madam! come Aquinus.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I attend your lordship. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Haraldus, Sueno, Helga, at a banquet.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: My lord, you honour us.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If we knew how to express our duties.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: No more ceremony,
Your loves engage me, if some discontents
Make me not seem unpleasant; yet I must
Confess I was more prompted to th'acceptance,
In hope to cure a melancholy.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: With your pardon,
It does too much usurp on your sweet nature,
But if your lordship please, there is a way
To banish all those thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I would call him doctor
That could assure me that.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I am of his
Opinion sir, and know the best receipt
I'th world for sadness.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Prithee what?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Good wine.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have heard 'em talk so, if I thought there were
That operation —

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Try sir.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: My humble duty — 'tis excellent wine!

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Helga.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Your lordship's servant.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis pleasant. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: It has spirit, will you please
Another trial, that prepares more sweetness,
Health to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: With your pardon, fill to me,
Your grace should have it last.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She is my mother.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: She is our royal mistress, heaven preserve her;
Does not your lordship feel more inclination
To mirth, there is no spell 'gainst sorrow, like
Two or three cups of wine.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Nothing believe't,
Will make your soul so active, take it liberally.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I dare not trust my brain.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You never tried.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: You'll never know the pleasure then of drinking
I have drunk myself into an emperor.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: In thy own thoughts.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Why is't not rare, that wine
Taken to the extent, should so delightfully
Possess the imagination, I have had my Queens
And concubines —

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Fine fancies.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: The King's health,
Give me't in greater volume, these are acorns
Sueno to thee, I'm sprightly but to look out.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: What rare things will the flowing virtue raise,
If but, the sight exalt you? to your grace,
The King's health.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let it come, I'll trespass once.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: That smile became you sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: This cup doth warm me,Drinks.
Methinks I could be merry.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Will your grace have any music?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Strike lustily. Music.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have begun no health yet gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Now you must honour us.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Health to the prince.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: That is your title sir,
As you are son to a Queen,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My father was no King, father? I'll drown
The memory of that name. Drinks.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: The prince Turgesius' health.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: He's not far off
By the court computation — happiness now
To prince Haraldus mistress.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: With devotion.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Alas, I am too young to have a mistress.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Sir, you must crown it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: These are compliments

div.stage: At court, where none must want a drinking mistress.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Methinks loud music should attend these healths —

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: So, shall we dance? Drinks.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: We want ladies.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am as light, thou shalt go for a lady.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Shall I? Dance.
Is not this better, than to sigh away
Our spirits now?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'm hot.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: A cup of wine is the most natural cooler.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You are my physician's gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Make it a health to my lord Gotharus. Drinks:
I'll pledge it as heartily as he were my father.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Whose father? Throws wine in Sueno's face.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Mine, I said.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Cry mercy.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis but so much wine lost, fill't again.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'll drink no more.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: What think you of a song? Song.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: A catch, to't boys.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Shall we to bed gentlemen?
I did not sleep last night.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: If your grace
desire to sleep, there's nothing to prepare it
Like tother cup.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A health to both your mistresses.Drinks

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You do us grace.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: There's hope of his conversion ▪

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am nos well, what wheels are in my brains?
Philosophy affirms the earth moves not,
'Tis here methinks confuted, gentlemen,
You must be fain to lead me to some couch,
Where I may take a nap, and then I'll thank you,
I'll come again tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Every day
For a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: That will make you a good fellow. Exit.

div.stage: Enter prince Turgesius, Reginaldus, soldiers marching, Olaus meets, they salute and whisper.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: You tell me wonders.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis all truth, we must
Stand on our guard, 'tis well we are provided.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Is it not some device to make us fear,
That at our entertainment we may find
Our joys more spacious.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: There is some device in't.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: It is not possible a father should
Be so unkind to his own blood and honour.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: My life was threatened.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Who durst threaten it?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The King your father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: O say not so good sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And if you please him not with your behaviour,
Your head may be soon humbled to the axe,
And sent a token of his love, to your stepdame
The Queen, I trifle not.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: For what sins
Hath angry heaven decreed to punish Norway,
And lay the scene of wrath in her own bowels?
I did suspect when none came forth to meet
Our victory, to have heard of some misfortune,
Some prodigies engendering: down with all
Our pride of war, the garlands we bring home
Will but adorn us for the sacrifice;
And while our hairs are decked with flowers and ribbons,
We shall but march more gloriously to death.
Are all good women dead within the kingdom,
There could be found none worth my father's love,
But one whose fame and honour is suspected?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Wouldst they were but suspected.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Marpisa?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Her preferment was no doubt
Gotharus' act, for which 'tis whispered,
She pays him fair conditions, while they both
Case up the King's eyes, or confine him to
Look through such cunning optics as they please.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I'll have his heart.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But how will you come by't?
He's safe in the King's bosom, who keeps warm
A serpent, till he find a time to gnaw
Out his preserver.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: We had died with honour
By the enemy's sword, something might have been read
In such a fall, as might have left no shame
Upon our story, since 'tis chance of war,
Not want of valour, gives the victory;
This shipwracks all, and eats into the soul
Of all our fame, it withers all the deeds
Is owing to our name.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Health to the prince,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Cortes, welcome, what news?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: These letters will inform his highness.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Sent, from the King Cortes? has he thought upon't?
Are we considerable at last, and shall
The lady Geugaw, that is parched upon
His throne, be counselled not to take too much
Upon her? will Gotharus give us leave
To be acquainted with the King again? ha!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: These letters came sir from Aquinus.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How?
I hope he mentions not the broken pate
I gave him, and complains on't to the prince,
I may be apt to make him an amends
With such another.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Read, I am planet-struck, cursed Gotharus!
What would the traitor have?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis here, I take it, he would have you sent
Yonder, and has taken order with Aquinus
For your conveyance hence, at both their charges;
But now you know the plot, you wo' not trust
Your life as he directs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Not trust Aquinus?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You are desperate, hark you, I do suspect him,
And I ha' cause, I broke his head at court
For his impertinent counsel, when I was
In passion with the King, you sha'not trust him,
This may be cunning to revenge himself,
I know he has a spirit, come you shall not
Be cheated of your life, while I have one
To counsel you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Uncle, I am unmoved,
He is a soldier, to that name and honour
I'll trust a prince's life, he dares not be
A traitor.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I have read that one prince was
So credulous, and scaped, but Alexander,
Though he were great, was not so wise a gentleman,
As heaven in that occasion might have made him,
The valiant confidence in his doctor, might
Have gnawn his bowels up, and where had been
My gallant Macedonian? come you shall
Consider on't.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I am resolved already,
March to the city, every thought doth more
Confirm me, passion will not let you see,
Good uncle with your pardon, the true worth
And inside of Aquinus, he is faithful,
Should I miscarry, 'tis my single life,
And 'tis obedience to give up our breath,
When fathers shall conspire their children's death

div.head: Act. 4.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You may surrender up your crown, 'twill show
Brave on Turgesius' temples, whose ambition
Expects it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nay Gotharus —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Has my care
Cast to prevent your shame, how to preserve
The glories you possess, by cutting off
A canker that would eat into your trunk,
And hinder your fair growth, and do you make
A scruple to be cured?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I did but mention,
And nature may excuse, he is my son.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The more your danger, when he dares be impious,
The forfeit of his duty in this bold
And hostile manner to affright your subjects,
And threaten you with articles, is already
The killing of your honour, and a treason
Nature abhors, a guilt heaven trembles at,
And you are bound in care of your own province,
To show your justice, and not be partial
To your own blood; but let your kingdom suffer,
Her heart be torn by civil wars; 'tis none
Of mine, and let him in the blood of many
Fathers, be made a King, your King; and you
That now command, be taught obedience,
Creep to your child, exchange your palace for
A prison, and be humbled till you think
Death a preferment, I have but a life —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Which I will cherish, be not passionate,
And I consent to all thou hast contained;
Thou art my friend.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I would be sir, your honest chirurgeon,
And when you have a gangrene in your limb,
Not flatter you to death, but tell you plainly
If you would live, the part so poisoned must be
Cut from your body.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And I won't shake
With horror of the wound, but meet my safety
And thank my best preserver; but art sure
Aquinus will be resolute?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Suspect not,
He is my creature.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: The prince your son —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is a bold traitor.
And they are rebels join with him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What of the prince Hormenus?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He is very near the city with his army.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Are the walls fortified?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They are?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We won't trust him, nor the ruffian
Olaus, that incendiary.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The Queen. Enter Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: There are more wounds in those sad accents,
Than their rebellion can give my kingdom.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: My boy, my child, Haraldus.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is sick, is dying sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Forbid it heavens, he was in health —

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But if I mean to see him
Alive , they say I must make haste,
The comforts of my life expire with him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The devils up in arms, and fates conspire
Against us.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mischiefs tumble like waves upon us.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Sir, it will be necessary
You lend your person to direct, what shall
Be further done i'th city, Aquinus hath
Charge of the gate and walls, that offer
The first view to the enemy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He is trusty, and
A daring soldier; what at stand Gotharus?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I was thinking of the Queen sir, and Haraldus,
And grieve for the sweet child.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Some fever, would my
Son were in his state, but soon we shall
Conclude his destiny, if Aquinus prosper;
But to the walls.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I attend, my very soul
Is in a sweat, Hormenus.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I wait on you. Exeunt:

div.stage: Enter prince Turgesius, Olaus, Cortes, Reginaldus, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: The gates are shut against us soldiers.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Let our engines
Tear 'em, and batter down the walls.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Good uncle,
Your counsel I obeyed i'th wars abroad,
We did there fight for honour, and might use
All the most horrid forms of death to fright
Our enemies, and cut our way to victory:
But give me leave to tell you sir, at home
Our conquest will be loss, and every wound
We give our country, is a crimson tear
From our own heart, they are a viperous brood
Gnaw through the bowels of their parent, I
Will rather die without a monument,
Then have it bear my name, to have defaced
One heap of stones.

div.stage: Enter Gotharus on the walls, ho. Aqui.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Gotharus on the walls?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Hormonus and Aquinus? now a speech,
And 'twere at gallows would become him better.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thus from my master, to the prince of Norway,
We did expect, and had prepared to meet
Your victory with triumphs, and with garlands
Due to your fate and valours, entertained you ▪
Nor has your army sacrificed so many
Warm drops of blood, as we have shot up prayers
That you might prosper, and return the pledge
Of all our hope and glory. But when pride
Of your own fames, and conquest in a war,
Hath poisoned the obedience of a son,
And tempted you to advance your sword, new bathed
in enemy's blood 'gainst your country's bosom;
Thus we receive you, and declare your piety,
And faith lost to your country, and your father.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My lord, all this concerns not me, we have
But done our duties, and return to lay
The trophies at his feet, whose justice did
Make us victorious more than our own valour,
And now without all titles but his son,
I dare hell's accusation, to blast
My humble thoughts.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Sir, give us leave to fear,
Not your own nature, calm as the soft air,
When no rude wind conspires a mutiny —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Leave rhetoric, and to'th point, why do not
The gates spread to receive us? and your joys
Shoot up in acclamations? I would have
Thy house give good example to the city ▪
And make us the first-born fire.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Good heaven knows,
How willingly I would sacrifice myself,
To do a grateful service to the prince:
And I could wish my lord, you were less passionate,
And not inflame his highness' gentle spirit
To these attempts.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am ignorant Gotharus
Of what you mean, where is the King my father?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Where a sad father is, to know his son
Bring arms against his life.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: How now Aquinus,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dare you be saucy?
O that gentleman
Is angry, his head aches with the remembrance of
My truncheon.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: 'Twas a valiant act,
And did become the greatness of Olaus,
Who by the privilege of his birth, may do
a wrong and boast it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Shall these grooms affront us?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Have you commission to be thus insolent,
They do not know us?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Yes, and in our hearts
Bleed, that our fears of your unjust demand,
Compel us to this separation.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Demands? is it injustice for a son
To ask his father's blessing? by thy duty
Gotharus, I command thee, tell my father
His son desires access, let me but speak with him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I have not in your absence sir neglected,
What did become my service to your highness,
To take his anger off.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What riddles this?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But let me with a pardon tell your grace,
The letters that you sent, were not so dutiful,
You were to blame, to chide and article
So with a King and father; yet I said,
And pawned my conscience 'twas no act of yours,
I mean entire, but wrought and formed by some
Rash spirits, to corrupt you with ambition,
Feeding your youth with thought of hasty empire
To serve their ends, whose counsel all this while
Did starve that sweetness in you we all hoped for.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Devices! more devices!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am amazed,
And if the King will not vouchsafe me conference,
I shall accuse thy cunning to have poisoned
My father's good opinion. Enter King.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Innocence
May thus be stained, pray let your justice clear me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What would our son?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Thus pay his filial duty.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Tis but counterfeit, if you bring no thought
To force our blessing in this rude manner, how
dare you approach? dismiss your soldiers.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Not the meanest knapsack,
That were a way to bring us to the mercy
Of wolves indeed, Gotharus grinds his teeth
Already at us.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We shall talk with you sir
Hereafter, I command thee by thy duty
Thou owest a father and a King, dismiss
Your troops.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ola.
sp.l: You shall not, that were fine,
So we may run our heads into their noose,
You give away your safety.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will not
Dispute my power, let my entreat prevail
For their dismissal.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You may dismiss
Your head and mine, and be laughed at, these men
Are honest, and dare fight for us.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I know
Their loves, and will rewait; dear, dear uncle.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How he prepares his tragedy Aquinus,
Let not thy hand shake.

sp.speaker: Aqu.
sp.l: I am resolute.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And I, for thy reward, 'tis done, the soldiers
Disperse already.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: If any mischief follow this,
Thank your credulity.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: May I now hope for access?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Descend Gotharus and Aquinus
To meet the prince, while he contains within
The piety of a son, we shall embrace him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: When I degenerate, let me be accursed
By heaven and you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Are you not pale to think on't.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: It puzzles me to think my father guilty.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I do not like things yet.

div.stage: As the prince is going forth, a pistol is discharged within, he falls.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: O I am shot, I am murdered.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Inhuman traitor, villain.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: So, so, his friend has saved my execution,
'Tis not safe for me to stay, they are both sped rarely. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O my dear cousin, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: In thy own bosom, thou hast killed thy son,
Convey his body, guard it safe, and this
Perfidious trunk I'll have it punished
Passed death, and scatter his torn flesh about
The world to affright mankind, thou art
