A murderer, no blood of mine ▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis done,
And all the guilt dies with Aquinus, fallen
By Olaus' sword most happily, who but
Prevented mine, this act concludes all fear.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He was my son, I must needs drop a tear.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It is not possible, he●●●●ch a favour
By excess of wine? he was all temperance.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: He had a soft and tender constitution,
Apt to be inflamed, they that are most abstemious,
Feel the disorder with more violence.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Where, who assisted him in this misfortune?
He had some company.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: He was invited
He says by Sueno, and Helga, to a banquet,
Where in their mirth, they careless of his health,
suffered him drink too much.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: They poisoned him,
Go apprehend the murderers of my child,
If he recover not, their death shall wait
Upon Haraldus; but pray you tell me gentlemen,
Is there no hope of life, have you not art
Enough to cure a favour?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: We find madam,
His disease more malignant by some thought
Or apprehensions of grief.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What grief?
You're all impostors, and are ignorant
But how to kill.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Is not my mother come?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes my dear son, and here shall weep myself
Till I turn Niobe, unless thou givest me
Some hope of thy own life.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I would say something
Were you alone.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Leave us; now my Haraldus,
How is it with my child?

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.l: I know you love me,
Yet I must tell you truth, I cannot live,
And let this comfort you, death will not come
Unwelcome to your son, I do not die
Against my will, and having my desires,
You have less cause to mourn.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What is't has made
The thought of life unpleasant, which does court
Thy dwelling here with all delights that nature
And art can study for thee, rich in all things
Thy wish can be ambitious of, yet all
These treasures nothing to thy mother's love,
Which to enjoy thee would defer a while
Her thought of going to heaven.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: O take heed mother, heaven
has a spacious ear and power to punish,
Your too much love with my eternal absence,
I beg your prayers and blessing.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou'rt dejected,
Have but a will and live.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis in vain mother.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sink with a favour into earth?
Look up, thou shalt not die.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have a wound within
You do not see, more killing than all favours.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: A wound? where? who has murdered thee?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Gotharus —

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha! furies persecute him.

sp.speaker: Ha ▪
sp.l: O pray for him!
'Tis my duty, though he gave me death,
He is my father.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How? thy father?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He told me so, and with that breath destroyed me,
I felt it strike upon my spirits; mother,
Would I had ne'er been born!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Believe him not.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: O do not add another sin to what
Is done already, death is charitable
To quit me from the scorn of all the world.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: By all my hopes Gotharus has abused thee,
Thou art the lawful burden of my womb,
Thy father, Altomarus.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Before whose spirit long since taken up,
To meet with saints and troops angelical,
I dare again repeat thou art his son.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ten thousand blessings now reward my mother!
Speak it again, and I may live, a stream
Of pious joy runs through me, to my soul
You've stroke a harmony next that in heaven;
Can you without a blush, call me your child,
and son of Altomarus? all that's holy
Dwell in your blood for ever, speak it once,
But once again.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Were it my latest breath,
Thou art his and mine.
Enough, my tears do flow
To give you thanks for't; I would you could resolve me
But one truth more, why did my lord Gotharus
Call me the issue of his blood?

sp.speaker: Queen,
sp.l: Alas, he thinks thou art —

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What are those words? I am undone
Again.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis too late to call 'em back, he thinks I am his son —

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have confessed too much, and tremble with
The imagination, forgive me child,
And heaven, if there be mercy to a crime
So black, as I must now to quit thy fears,
Say I have been guilty off, we have been sinful,
And I was not unwilling to oblige
His active brain for thy advancement, by
Abusing his belief thou were't his own,
But thou hast no such stain, thy birth is innocent,
Or may I perish ever, 'tis a strange
Confession to a child, but it may drop
A balsam to thy wound; live my Haraldus,
If not for this, to see my penitence,
And with what tears I'll wash away my sin.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am no bastard then.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou art not.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: But I am not found while you are lost,
No time can restore you,
My spirits faint.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Will nothing comfort thee?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My duty to the King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He's here. Enter King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How is't Haraldus?
Death sits in's face.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Give me you blessing, and within my heart
I'll pray you may have many, my soul flies
Above this vain world, good mother close mine eyes

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Never died so much sweetness in his years.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Be comforted, I have lost my son too,
The prince is slain, how now.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Justice upon the murderer of my son,
This villain Helga, and his companion
Sueno, have killed him, where's the other?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Fled madam,
But Helga does confess he made him drunk.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: But not dead drunk, I do beseech you madam.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Look here what your base surfeit has destroyed.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: 'Twas sueno as well as I, my lord Gotharus
Gave us commission for what we did.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Again Gotharus, sure he plotted this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Hang him up straight.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: I left no drink behind me,
If I must die let me have equal justice,
And let one of your guard drink me to death sir;
Or if you please to let me live till
Sueno is taken, we will drink and reel
Out of the world together.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Hence, and hang him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Sir, you must make provision against
New danger, discontent is broke into
A wild rebellion, and many of your subjects
Gather in tumults, and give out they will
Revenge the prince's death.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This I did fear,
Where's Gotharus? O my fright, my conscience,
has furies in't, where's Gotharus? —

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not in the court.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I tremble with confusions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I am resolved, my joys are all expired,
Nor can ambition more concern me now,
Gotharus has undone me in the death
Of my loved son, his fate is next, while I
Move resolute I'll command his destiny. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How are we lost, the prince Turgesius' death
Is of no use, since 'tis unprofitable
To the great hope we stored up in Haraldus,
It was a cursed plot directed me
To raise his spirit, by those giddy engines
That have undone him, their souls reel to hell for't
How will Marpisa weep herself into
The obscure shades, and leave me here to grow
A statue with the wonder of our fate.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Although
I am not partner of your joys or comfort,
Yet let your cruelty be so mindful of me
I may divide your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Would thy sufferings
Could ease me of the weight, I would
Empty my heart of all that's ill, to sink thee,
And bury thee alive, thy sight is hateful,
Ask me not why, but in obedience
Fly hence into some wilderness. The Queen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Great Queen, did any sorrow lade my bosom,
But what does almost melt it for Haraldus,
your presence would revive me, but it seems
Our hopes and joys in him grew up so mighty,
Heaven became jealous, we should undervalue
The bliss of th'other world, and build in him
A richer paradise.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have mourned already
A mother's part, and fearing thy excess
Of grief, present myself to comfort thee,
Tears will not call him back, and 'twill become us
Since we two are the world unto ourselves,
(Nothing without the circle of our arm's
Precious and welcome) to take heed our grief
Make us not over soon, like him that dead,
And our blood useless.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Were you present madam,
When your son died?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I was.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And did you weep;
And wish him live, and would not heaven at
Your wish, return his wandering ghost again?
Your voice should make another out of atoms;
I do adore the harmony, and from
One pleasant look, draw in more blessings
Than death knows how to kill.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He is recovered from his passion.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What's this? ha?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Here, like a sudden winter
Struck on my heart, I am not well o'th sudden, ha?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My lord, make use of this, 'tis cordial,
sp.stage: Gives him a box of poison.
sp.l: I am often subject to these passions,
And dare not walk without this ivory box
To prevent danger, they are pleasant,
'Tis a most happy opportunity.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Let me present my thanks to my preserver,
And kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Our lips will meet more lovingly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My heart will break.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your lady, we are betrayed,
She see us kiss, and I shall hate her for't.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Does this offend your virtue?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You're merciless,
You shall be a less ▪ tyrant sir to kill me,
Injurious Queen!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Shall I be here affronted?
I shall not think Gotharus worth my love,
To let her breath forth my dishonour, which
Her passion hath already dared to publish,
Nor wanted she before an impudence
To throw this poison in my face.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I'll tame her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I won't curse you madam, but you are
The cruelest of all woman kind,
I am prepared to meet your tyrannies.

div.stage: Enter Gotharus with a pistol, at the other door, a servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord,
We are undone, the common people are
In arms, and violently assault our house,
Threatening your lordship with a thousand deaths,
For the good prince, whose murder they exclaim
Contrived by you.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The friends of hell will show more mercy to me,
Where shall I hide me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Alas they'll kill me too.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There's no staying, they have broke the wall of the first court,
Down at some window sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Help me, oh help me, i' me lost.
Within —down with the doors,
This way, this way. Enter rebels.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: He that first moves this way
Comes on his death, I can dispatch but one,
And take your choice.
Alas good madam, we do not come to trouble you
You have sorrow enough, we would talk
With my lord your pagan husband.
Ay, ay, where is he?
That traitor.
Murderer of our prince.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You're not well informed,
Aquinus killed the prince.
But by my lord's correction
We know his heart, and do mean to eat it.
Therefore let him appear, knock down the lady
You with the long bill.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How dare you run the hazard of your lives
And fortunes, thus like outlaws, without authority
To break into our houses, when you have done,
What fury leads you to 't, you will buy too dear
Repentance at the gallows.
Hang the gallows, and give us my lord your husband.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He's escaped madam, now they may search.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: But where's the Queen, she must not be betrayed.
This way, this way, he got out of a window,
And leaped a wall, follow, follow.
Within —follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O my poor Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, you are secure, though you pursued
My death, I wish you safety,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have been
too cruel, but my fate compelled me to't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am become the extremest of all miseries.
O my unhappy lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Helga is hanged, what will become of me?
I think I were best turn rebel, there's no hope
To walk without a guard, and that I shall not
Want to the gallows, heathen halberdiers
Are used to have a care, and do rejoice
To see men have good ends.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I am pursued.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: My lord Gotharus? worse and worse, o for a mist before his eyes.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You sha'not betray me sir.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Hold my lord, I am your servant, honest Sueno.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Sueno, off with that case, it may secure me,
Quickly, or —

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: O my lord, you shall command my skin,
Alas poor gentleman, I'm glad I have it
To do your lordship service.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Nay, your beard too?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Yes, yes, any thing:
Alas my good lord, how comes this?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Leave your untimely prating, help,
You'll not betray me.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I'll first be hanged.
Within— Follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Hell stop their throats; so, so, now thy reward

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: It was my duty, troth sir I will have nothing.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Yes, take that, and that, for killing of Haraldus. Wounds him.
Now I'm sure you will not prate.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: O murder.
Within— Follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I cannot scape, o help invention.

div.stage: He bloodies himself with Sueno's blood, and falls down as dead.

sp.l: This way they say he went, what's he?
One of our company I think,
Who killed him?
I know not.
Let's away, if we can find that traitor,
He shall pay for all ▪
O that I had him here, I'd teach him —
This way, this way.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Oh.
Stay, there's one groans.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: O —
Nay 'twas hereabouts , another dead?
He has good clothes, Gotharus? the very cur.
'Tis Gotharus, I have seen the dog.
'Tis he, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Oh.Exit Gotha.
Now 'tis not he, if thou canst speak my friend —

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Gotharus murdered me, and shifted clothes,
He cannot be far off, o.
That's he that lies dead yonder, oh that he were
Alive again, that we might kill him one after another.
He's gone:
The devil he is, follow, follow.
This way, he cannot scape us, farewell friend,
I'll do thee a courtesy.
Follow, follow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: So, so, in this disguise you may to'th army,
Who though they seem to scatter, are to meet
by my directions, honest Aquinus, you
You wait on the prince, but sir —Whispers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Were you not wounded?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I prepared a privy coat, for that I knew Gotharus
Would have been too busy with my flesh else,
But he thinks I'm slain by the Duke, and hugs
His fortune in't.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: You'll follow.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And bring you news, perhaps the rabble are
In hot pursuit after the politician,
He cannot scape them, they'll tear him like
So many hungry mastiffs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I could wish they had him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Lose no time, Cortes stay you with me,
Not that I think my house will want your guard.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Command me sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Was ever such a practice by a father,
To take away his son's life?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I would hope he may not be so guilty, yet I know not
How his false terrors multiplied by the art
Of this Gotharus may prevail upon him,
And win consent.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Aquinus has been faithful,
And deceived all their treasons, but the prince
Is still thought dead, this empty coffin shall
Confirm the people in his funeral,
To keep their thoughts revengeful,
Within.follow, follow —
Till we are possessed of him that plotted all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The cry draws this way,
They are excellent bloodhounds.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: As you are men, defend me from the rage
Of the devouring multitude; I have
deserved your anger, and a death, but let not
My limbs inhumanely be torn by them,
Oh save me.
Within.follow, foll —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Blessed occasion.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I am forced to take your house, and now implore
Your mercy, but to rescue me from them,
And be your own revenger, yet my life
Is worth your preservation for a time,
Do it, and I'll reward you with a story
You'll not repent to know.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You cannot be safe here,
Their rage is high, and every door
Must be left open to their violence,
Unless you will obscure you in this coffin,
Prepared for the sweet prince that's murdered,
And but expects his body which is now embalming.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: That, oh you're charitable.
Within.follow, fol —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Their noise is thunder to my soul,
So, so.

sp.speaker: Ola.
sp.l: How now gentlemen, what means this tumult,
Do you know that I possess this dwelling?

sp.speaker: Rebel
sp.l: Yes my lord,
But we were told my lord Gotharus entered,
And we beseech you give him to our justice,
He is the common enemy, and we know he killed the prince.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You may search if you please,
He can presume of small protection here,
But I much thank you for your loyalties,
And service to the prince, whose bloodless ruins
Are there, and do but wait when it will please
his father to reverse a cruel sentence,
That keeps him from a burial with his ancestors,
We are forbid to do him rights of funeral.
How, not bury him?
Forbid to bury our good prince? we'll bury him,
And see what priest dare not assist us.
Not bury him? we'll do't, and carry his body in triumph
Through the city, and see him laid i'th great tombs
Not bury our prince? that were a jest indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis their love and duty.
We'll pull the church down, but we'll have our will.
Dear prince, how sweet he smells.
Come countrymen march, and see who dares
Take his body from us.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You cannot help.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: They'll bury him alive.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He's in a fright.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: So may all traitors thrive. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 5.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O I am lost, and my soul bleeds to think
By my own dotage upon thee.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I was cursed
When I first saw thee, poor wind-shaken King!
I have lost my son.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thy honour impious woman,
Of more price than a son, or thy own life,
I had a son too, whom my rashness sent
To another world, my poor Turgesius,
what sorcery of thy tongue and eyes betrayed me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I would I had been a basilisk, to have shot
A death to thy dissembling heart, when I
Gave myself up thy Queen; I was secure,
Till thou with the temptation of greatness
And flattery, didst poison my sweet peace,
And shall thy base fears leave me now a prey
To rebels?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I had been happy to have left
Thee sooner, but be gone, get to some wilderness
Peopled with serpents, and engender with
Some dragon like thyself.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Dost laugh thou prodigy? thou shame of woman?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, and despise thee dotard, vex till thy soul
Break from thy rotten flesh, I will be merry
At thy last groan.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O my poor boy! my son!
His wound is printed here, that false Gotharus,
Your wanton goat I fear, practised with thee
His death.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: 'Twas thy own act and timorous heart, in hope
To be secure, I glory in the mention
Thou murderer of thy son.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O sir, if ever, stand upon your guard,
The army which you thought scattered and broke,
Is grown into a great and threatening body,
Lead by the Duke Olaus your loved uncle,
Is marching hither, all your subjects fly to him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Curse on thy spleen, is this a time for laughter,
When horror should afflict thy guilty soul?
Hence mischief.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not to obey thee, (Shadow of a King)
Am I content to leave thee, and but I won't
Prevent thy greater sorrow and vexation,
Now I would kill thee coward.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ay, ay, who comes to your rescue?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Are all fled?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Slave's do it naturally.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Canst thou hope to scape?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I am mistress of my fate, and do not fear
Their inundation, their army coming,
It does prepare my triumph, they shall give
Me liberty, and punish thee to live.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Undone, forsaken, miserable King!

div.stage: Enter prince, Olaus, Cortes, Aquinus, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Worthy Aquinus, I must honour thee,
Thou hast preserved us all, thy service will
Deserve a greater monument than thanks.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Thank the Duke, for breaking of my pate.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I know 'twas well bestowed, but we have now
Proof of thy honest heart.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: But what with your highness' favour, do you mean
To do with your father?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Pay my duty to him,
He may be sensible of his cruelty,
And not repent to see me live.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But with your favour, something else must be
Considered, there's a thing he calls his Queen,
A limb of Lucifer, she must be roasted
For the army's satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: They'll ne'er digest her,
The King's hounds may be kept hungry
Enough perhaps, and make a feast upon her.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I wonder how the rabble will bestow
the coffin.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Why, they'll bury him alive
I hope.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Did they suppose my body there?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I'm sorry, he will fare so much the better,
I would the Queen were there to comfort him,
O they would smell, and sweat together rarely.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He dare as soon be damned as make a noise,
Or stir, or cough.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: If he should sneeze.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis his best course to go into the ground
With silence.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: March on, stay, what trumpets that?

div.stage: Enter rebels with a trumpet before the coffin marching.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: They are no enemies, I know the coffin.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: What rusty regiment ha' we here?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: They are going to bury him, he's not yet discovered;
O do not hinder 'em, 'tis a work of charity:
Yet now I do consider better on't,
You may do well to show yourself, that may
Be a means to waken the good gentleman,
And make some sport before the rascal smell,
And yet he's in my nostril, he has perfumed
His box already.

sp.speaker: Om. rebel
sp.l: 'Tis he, 'tis he, the prince alive! heigh.

div.stage: They see the prince throw down the coffin, and run to kneel and embrace him.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: What would he give but for a knife to cut
His own throat now?

sp.speaker: Om. rebel.
sp.l: Our noble prince alive?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: That owes himself to all your loves.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: What? what trinkets ha' you there?

sp.speaker: Rebel
sp.l: The Duke Olaus told us 'twas the prince's body,
which we resolved to bury with magnificence.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis better as it is.

sp.speaker: 2. Rebel
sp.l: There's something in't, my shoulder is still sensible,
Let's search, stand off —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Now do you sent him gentlemen? he would forgive
The hangman to dispatch him out o'th way;
Now will these mastiffs use him like a cat,
Most dreadful rogues at an execution:
Now, now.

sp.speaker: 1. Rebel
sp.l: 'Tis a man, ha Gotharus, the thing we whet our teeth for.

sp.speaker: Om. rebel
sp.l: Out with the traitor, and with the murderer, heigh, drag him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I told you.

sp.speaker: 1 rebel
sp.l: Hold, know your duty fellow renagades,
We do beseech thee high and mighty prince,
Let us dispose of what we brought, this traitor
He was given us by the Duke, fortune has
Thrown him into our teeth.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And they'll devour him.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We beseech your highness.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I do acknowledge it, good sir grant their boon,
And try the cannibals.
I'll have an arm.
I'll have a leg, I am a shoemaker,
His shinbone may be useful.
I want a sign, give me his head.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Stay, let's first see him, is he not stifled?
I had rather my wife were speechless.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The coffin sir was never close.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: He does not stir.
We'll make him stir, hang him, he's but asleep.
He's dead, hum.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dead? Then the devil is not so wise as I took him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: He's dead, and has prevented all their fury.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He was not smothered, the coffin had air enough.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: He might ha' lived to give these gentlemen some content.

sp.speaker: 1 rebel
sp.l: O let us tear his limbs.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Let none use any violence to his body,
I fear he has met reward above your punishment.
Let me have but his clothes.
He is a tailor.
Only to cut out a suit for a traitor by 'em,
Or any man, my conscience would wish hanged.
Let me have a button for a relic —

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: There is some mystery in his death.
The King? obscure a little nephew —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To whom now must I kneel? where is the King?
For I am nothing, and deserve to be so,
Unto you uncle must I bow, and give
My crown, pray take it, with it give me leave
To tell you, what it brings the hapless wearer,
Beside the outside glory: for I am
Read in the miserable fate of Kings.
You think it glorious to command, but are
More subject than the poorest pays you duty,
And must obey your fears, your want of sleep,
Rebellion from your vassals, wounds even from
Their very tongues, whose quietness you sweat for,
For whose dear health you waste, and fright your
Strength to paleness, and your blood into a frost.
You are not certain of a friend or servant,
To build your faith upon, your life is but
Your subjects murmur, and your death their sacrifice;
When looking passed yourself, to make them blessed
In your succession, which a wife must bring you;
You may give up your liberty for a smile
as I ha' done, and in your bosom cherish
More danger than a war or famine brings,
Or if you have a son — my spirits fail me
At naming of a son.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: O my dear father.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha! do not fright me in my tears, which should
Be rather blood, for yielding to thy death,
I have let fall my penitence, though I was
Counselled by him whose truth I now suspect,
In the amaze and puzzle of my state —

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Dear sir, let not one thought afflict you more,
I am preserved to be your humble son still,
Although Gotharus had contrived my ruin,
'Twas counterplotted by this honest captain.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I know not what to credit, art Turgesius?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And do account your blessing, and forgiveness
(If I have erred) above the whole world's empire ▪
The army sir is yours.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Upon conditions —

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Good sir — and all safety meant your person ▪

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Right, but for your Gipsy Queen, that cockatrice.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: She's lost.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The devil find her.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: She's false.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That gentleman
Jack in a box, if he could speak,
Would clear that point.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Forgive me gentle boy.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Dear sir no more.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Best dismiss these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The prince's bounty, now you may go home;
And d'ye hear, be drunk tonight , the cause requires it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: We'll show ourselves good subjects.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Heaven bless the King and prince, and the good Duke. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My comforts are too mighty, let me pour
More blessings on my boy.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sir, I am blessed ▪
If I stand fair in your opinion.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And welcome ▪ good Olaus.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You're deceived,
I am a ruffian, and my head must off
To please the monkey madam that bewitched you,
For being too honest to you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We are friends.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Upon condition that you will —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Now have I forgotten what I would have,
O that my lady Circe that transformed you,
May be sent — whither? I ha' forgotten again,
To the devil, any whither, far enough:
A curse upon her, she troubles me both when
I think on her, and when I forget her.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Gotharus' wife, the sorrowful Albina.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: If pity dwell within your royal bosom,
Let me be heard; I come to find a husband,
I'll not believe what the hard hearted rebels
Told me, that he is dead, (They loved him not ▪
And wish it so) for you would not permit
His murder here. You gave me, sir, to him
In holy marriage, I'll not say, what sorrow
My poor heart since hath been acquainted with,
But give him now to me, and I'll account
No blessing like that bounty; where, o where
Is my poor lord? none tell me? are you all
Silent, or deaf as rocks? yet they sometimes
Do with their hollow murmurs, answer men.
This does increase my fears, none speak to me?
I ask my lord from you sir, you once loved him,
he had your bosom, who hath torn him thence?
Why do you shake your head? and turn away?
Can you resolve me sir? the prince alive?
Whose death they would revenge upon Gotharus.
O let me kiss your hand, a joy to see
You safe, doth interrupt my grief, I may
Hope now my lord is safe too, I like not
That melancholy gesture; why do you make
So dark your face, and hide your eyes, as they
Would show an interest in sorrow with me.
Where is my lord? can you or any tell me
Where I may find the comfort of mine eyes,
My husband; or but tell me that he lives,
And I will pray for you — then he is dead
Indeed I fear.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Poor lady.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Madam be comforted.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why that's well said, I thank you gentle sir,
You bid me be comforted, blessing on you,
Show me now reason for it, tell me something
I may believe.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Madam, your husband's dead.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And did you bid me sir be comforted
For that? o you were cruel ▪ dead? who murdered him?
For though he loved not me in life, I must
Revenge his death.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Alas you cannot.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No?
Will not heaven hear me think you? for I'll pray
That horror may pursue the guilty head
Of his black murderer, you do not know
How fierce and fatal is a widow's curse;
Who killed him? say.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: We know not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You're unjust.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Pursue not sorrow with such inquisition
Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not I? who hath more interest?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The knowledge of what circumstance deprived him
Of life, will not avail to his return;
Or if it would, none here know more, than that
He was brought hither dead in that enclosure.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: In that coffin lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Was it charity
Made this provision for him? o my lord
Now may I kiss thy withered lip, discharge
Upon thy bosom a poor widow's tears;
There's something tempts my heart to show more duty,
And wait on thee to death, in whose pale dress
Thou dost invite me to be reconciled.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Remove that coffin.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You're uncharitable;
Is't not enough that he is robbed of life
Among you, but you'll rob me of his body?
Poor remnant of my lord; I have not had
Indeed so many kisses a great while,
Pray do not envy me, for sure I sha'not
Die of this surfeit, he thought not I was
So near to attend him in his last and long
Progress, that built this funeral tenement
Without a room for me; the sad Albina
Must sleep by her dead lord, I feel death coming,
And as it did suspect, I durst not look
On his grim visage, he has drawn a curtain
Of mist before my eyes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Look to the lady.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Look to Albina, our physicians,
There is not so much virtue more i'th kingdom:
If she survive this passion, she is worth
A prince, and I will court her as my blessing.
Say, is there hope?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: There is.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Above your lives preserve her.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: With our best art and care.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: She has almost made me woman too; but
Come to other business.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Is not this the Queen?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The Queen of hell, give her no hearing, but
Shoot, shoot her presently without more repentance,
There is a lecherous devil in her eye,
Give him more fire, his hell's not hot enough,
Now shoot.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Be temperate good sir.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay let his choleric highness be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: She is shot-free.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The prince alive? where is Gotharus?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Your friend that was.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It is confessed.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Your stallion.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He has more titles sure.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Let but some strangle her in her own hair.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The office will become a noble hangman.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Whore —

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'll not spend my breath upon thee,
I have more use on't, does Gotharus live?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: You may conjecture madam, if you turn
Your eyes upon that object.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It has wrought then.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What has wrought?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: His physic sir,
For the state megrim.
A wholesome poison, which in his poor fears,
And fainting when the rebels first pursued him,
It was my happiness to minister
In my poor boy's revenge, killed by his practice.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Poisoned.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: She is turned doctor.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He becomes
Death's pale complexion, and now I'm prepared

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: To die.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Prepared to be damned, a seven years killing
Will be too little.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I pity your poor rage,
I sha'not stay so long, nor shall you have
The honour sir to kill me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: No, let me try.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dost thou laugh hellcat?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, and scorn all your furies, I was not
So improvident, to give Gotharus all
My cordial, you may trust the operation,
Here's some to spare, if any have a mind
To taste, and be assured, will you my lord?
'Twill purge your choler rarely.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I'll not be your patient I thank you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: This box was ever my companion,
Since I grew wicked with that politician,
To prevent shameful death, nor am I coy
To pleasure a friend in't.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Devil's charity.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It works with method, and doth kill discreetly
Without a noise, your Mercury is a rude
And troublesome destroyer to this medicine;
I feel it gently seize upon my vitals,
'Tis now the time to steal into my heart.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Hast thou no thought of heaven?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, I do think
Sometimes, but have not heart enough to pray;
Some vapour now rises 'twixt me and heaven,
I cannot see't, lust and ambition ruined me:
if greatness were a privilege i'th other
World, it were a happiness to die a Queen,
I find my conscience too late, 'tis bloody,
And full of stains, o I have been so wicked,
'Twere almost impudence to ask a pardon,
Yet for your own sakes pity me; survive
All happy, and if you can, forgive, forgive.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Those accents yet may be repentance.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: See's dead.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Some take their bodies hence.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Let them have burial.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis in thee Turgesius
To dispose all, to whom I give my crown;
Salute him King by my example.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Stay,
Upon your duty stay, will you be traitors,
Consent your lawful King should be deposed?
Sir, do not wound your son, and lay so great
A stain upon his hopeful, his green honour,
I now enjoy good men's opinions,
This change will make 'em think I did conspire,
And force your resignation, were it still
By justice and yourself, it shall not touch
My brow, till death translate you to a kingdom
More glorious, and you leave me to succeed,
Bettered by your example in the practice
Of a King's power and duty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This obedience
Will with excess of comfort kill thy father,
And hasten that command thou wouldst decline.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Receive this captain, and reward his faith
To you and me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Be captain of our guard.
And my good uncle, to your ear I leave
The soldiers, let the largesse speak our bounty
And your love.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ay, this sounds well fellow soldiers,
Trust me beside your pay for the King's bounty.
Within Sol.heaven preserve
The King and prince.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Not a short prayer for me?

sp.speaker: Om. Sol.
sp.l: Heaven bless the Duke, heaven bless the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Why so, money will do much.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A bright day shines upon us, come my son,
Too long a stranger to the court, it now
Shall bid thee welcome, I do feel my years
Slide off, and joy drown sorrow in my tears.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
